div1.p: Kean finds that Wood's book is a well-written depiction of the yellow fever demonstration.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Albert E. Truby, May 20, 1943
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
May 20th/43
My dear Truby
div1.p:
It was a real pleasure to
get the Post card which came last
week from you & Col Hench and to
know that you had talked for
two days over the Episode of 1900!
Meanwhile Mrs Laura N. Wood
has beat you to it. Her “Walter Reed
Doctor in Uniform ' Illustrated by
Douglas Duer. Printed by Julian
Messuer Inc New York for the
Junior Literary Guild is in print
and in my possession since April 12th
It is intended for readers in their teens
but is good reading for grown-ups
2
As I told her she has taken the more
difficult dramatic way of uniting the
story by having the dramatis personal
tell it by reported conversations.
This is of course a more vivacious
way but it involves the large
responsibility of knowing or
imagining the personality and
character of each speaker.
It begins with Reed as a boy of 13
when his father wakes him up to tell
him & his brother that the Yankees
are coming and to take the horses
into the woods to hide them.
I think she has dug up quite a lot
of information about his youth and
has told the story of the yellow fever
Demonstration clearly and well.

There are errors of course but none
I think of great importance.
I really have not get ready it criti-
cally however, as it came during
the week of the dedication of the T.J.
memorial when things were in rather
a whorl here. I was given five
books that week, four of them by the
authors and have not yet got
through them all. Mrs Wood says
that the issue of her books is delay-
ed at the bindery but that she is
going to send you a copy and one
to Colonel Hench as soon as she
can get them. She pays you both
grateful credit for your help to
her, and you for your generosity in
C2
B5
4
litting her use material which you
were using in your forth coming
book. That in the way should now
be making its appearance and
I am eager to see it.

I suppose Hench told you all about
his new baby and Mrs Hench's
visit to Colorado Springs.
He also told you doubtless of the
troubles that all these new men had
because they did not have any
manual of the Medical Dept. It
was a great piece of folly for the
Gen. Staff to have abolished it and
also for the General Hospitals to be
taken a way from the direct control
of the S.G.O. But I cannot go into that
here and now.

Goodly & cordial regard
to Mrs Truby
